unnormalised: SpiceJet flight SG-420 from Delhi to Mumbai faced a slight delay, not because of engine trouble, but because Mr. Sharma couldn't find his PNR number. He swore it was "somewhere between my Aadhaar and my PAN card picture!" Took him a whole 15 minutes, holding up the entire boarding process.
normalised: Spice Jet flight S-G four hundred and twenty from Delhi to Mumbai faced a slight delay, not because of engine trouble, but because Mister Sharma couldn't find his P-N-R number. He swore it was "somewhere between my Aadhaar and my P-A-N card picture!" Took him a whole fifteen minutes, holding up the entire boarding process.

unnormalised: Turns out, the poor fellow had accidentally used his wife's frequent flyer number (AI123456789) instead of his own (SG987654321) when he booked the tickets! Talk about confusing your travel documents! The airline staff, bless their patient souls, finally sorted it out.
normalised: Turns out, the poor fellow had accidentally used his wife's frequent flyer number (A-I one two three four five six seven eight nine) instead of his own (S-G nine eight seven six five four three two one) when he booked the tickets! Talk about confusing your travel documents! The airline staff, bless their patient souls, finally sorted it out.

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Keep your travel identifiers straight, folks! Mixing up your PNR with your UAN might just make you a viral sensation, and not in a good way. Remember, travel should be about the destination, not the destination of your lost booking reference!
normalised: Moral of the story? Keep your travel identifiers straight, folks! Mixing up your P-N-R with your U-A-N might just make you a viral sensation, and not in a good way. Remember, travel should be about the destination, not the destination of your lost booking reference!
